answer_html: \(0=f(c) - (2c+3)\) or, in other words, f(c) = 2c+3, which is what we had to show.
answer_latex:
$0=f(c) - (2c+3)$  or, in other words, \emph{f}(\emph{c}) =
2\emph{c}+3, which is what we had to show.
hints_html:
What theorem have you learned that applies to functions that are continuous on a closed interval? How could you use it for this problem?

The Intermediate Value Theorem states that if \(f\) is a continuous function on a closed interval [a,b ], and N is any number between \(f\)(a) and \(f\)(b), there exists a c  for which \(f\)(c)=N.
hints_latex:
What theorem have you learned that applies to functions that are
continuous on a closed interval? How could you use it for this problem?

The Intermediate Value Theorem states that if $f$ is a continuous function
on a closed interval {[}\emph{a},\emph{b} {]}, and \emph{N} is any
number between $f$(a) and $f$(b), there exists a \emph{c} ~for which
$f$(c)=\emph{N}.
hints_raw:
What theorem have you learned that applies to functions that are continuous on a closed interval?  How could you use it for this problem?
The Intermediate Value Theorem states that if &fnof; is a continuous function on a closed interval [''a'',''b'' ], and ''N'' is any number between &fnof;(a) and &fnof;(b), there exists a ''c'' &nbsp;for which &fnof;(c)=''N''.
sols_html:
We want to use the intermediate value theorem, as suggested by the hints. To do this we have to combine the two given functions \(f\) and y = 2x + 3 to one. So define

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle h(x) = f(x)-(2x+3)\end{aligned}\]

for x in the interval [0,1]. The function \(f\) crosses the line y = 2x + 3 when both functions are equal, i.e. at zeros of the function h. Since we are asked to show they cross at least one, we have to show that the function h has at least one zero. In other words, we need to show that there exists a value c in [0,1] such that h(c) = 0.

To show this we need to make use of the fact that the range of the function \(f\) is in [3,5], i.e.

\[\begin{aligned} 3 \leq f(x) \leq 5\end{aligned}\]

for any value of x in the domain [0,1] of the function \(f\). This implies that

\[\begin{aligned} h(0) = f(0) - (2(0)+3) = f(0)-3 \geq 3-3 = 0.\end{aligned}\]

and

\[\begin{aligned} h(1) = f(1) - (2(1)+3) = f(1)-5 \leq 5-5 = 0.\end{aligned}\]

Now, in the case that either h(0) or h(1) actually takes the value 0, we are done because we have found a zero of h.

In the case that neither takes the value zero, then we know that

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle h(1) < 0 < h(0)\end{aligned}\]

This is where the Intermediate Value Theorem shines: h is a continuous function on [0,1], hence for any value N between h(0) and h(1) there exists a number c = c(N) such that

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle h(c) = N.\end{aligned}\]

Since we have shown that h(0) is negative and h(1) is positive, we can choose that value N to be exactly zero and thus the Intermediate Value Theorem guarantees the existence of a number c in the interval [0,1] such that h(c) = 0.

Conclusion: At this value c we have that

\[\begin{aligned} 0 = h(c) = f(c) - (2c+3)\end{aligned}\]

or, in other words, f(c) = 2c+3, which is what we had to show.
sols_latex:
We want to use the intermediate value theorem, as suggested by the
hints. To do this we have to combine the two given functions $f$ and
\emph{y} = 2\emph{x} + 3 to one. So define

\begin{align*}
\displaystyle h(x) = f(x)-(2x+3)
\end{align*}

for \emph{x} in the interval {[}0,1{]}. The function $f$ crosses the line
\emph{y} = 2\emph{x} + 3 when both functions are equal, i.e. at zeros of
the function \emph{h}. Since we are asked to show they cross at least
one, we have to show that the function \emph{h} has at least one zero.
In other words, we need to show that there exists a value \emph{c} in
{[}0,1{]} such that \emph{h}(\emph{c}) = 0.

To show this we need to make use of the fact that the range of the
function $f$ is in {[}3,5{]}, i.e.

\begin{align*}
3 \leq f(x) \leq 5
\end{align*}

for any value of \emph{x} in the domain {[}0,1{]} of the function $f$.
This implies that

\begin{align*}
h(0) = f(0) - (2(0)+3) = f(0)-3 \geq 3-3 = 0.
\end{align*} and

\begin{align*}
h(1) = f(1) - (2(1)+3) = f(1)-5 \leq 5-5 = 0.
\end{align*}

Now, in the case that either \emph{h}(0) or \emph{h}(1) actually takes
the value 0, we are done because we have found a zero of \emph{h}.

In the case that neither takes the value zero, then we know that

\begin{align*}
\displaystyle h(1) < 0 < h(0)
\end{align*}

This is where the Intermediate Value Theorem shines: \emph{h} is a
continuous function on {[}0,1{]}, hence for any value \emph{N} between
\emph{h}(0) and \emph{h}(1) there exists a number \emph{c} =
\emph{c}(\emph{N}) such that

\begin{align*}
\displaystyle h(c) = N.
\end{align*}

Since we have shown that \emph{h}(0) is negative and \emph{h}(1) is
positive, we can choose that value \emph{N} to be exactly zero and thus
the Intermediate Value Theorem guarantees the existence of a number
\emph{c} in the interval {[}0,1{]} such that \emph{h}(\emph{c}) = 0.

Conclusion: At this value \emph{c} we have that

\begin{align*}
0 = h(c) = f(c) - (2c+3)
\end{align*} or, in other words, \emph{f}(\emph{c}) =
2\emph{c}+3, which is what we had to show.
sols_raw:
We want to use the intermediate value theorem, as suggested by the hints. To do this we have to combine the two given functions &fnof; and ''y'' = 2''x'' + 3 to one. So define

:<math>
\displaystyle h(x) = f(x)-(2x+3)
</math>

for ''x'' in the interval [0,1]. The function &fnof; crosses the line ''y'' = 2''x'' + 3 when both functions are equal, i.e. at zeros of the function ''h''. Since we are asked to show they cross at least one, we have to show that the function ''h'' has at least one zero. In other words, we need to show that there exists a value ''c'' in [0,1] such that ''h''(''c'') = 0.

To show this we need to make use of the fact that the range of the function &fnof; is in [3,5], i.e.

:<math>
3 \leq f(x) \leq 5
</math>

for any value of ''x'' in the domain [0,1] of the function &fnof;. This implies that

:<math>
h(0) = f(0) - (2(0)+3) = f(0)-3 \geq 3-3 = 0.
</math>
and
:<math>
h(1) = f(1) - (2(1)+3) = f(1)-5 \leq 5-5 = 0.
</math>

Now, in the case that either ''h''(0) or ''h''(1) actually takes the value 0, we are done because we have found a zero of ''h''.

In the case that neither takes the value zero, then we know that
:<math>
\displaystyle h(1) < 0 < h(0)
</math>

This is where the Intermediate Value Theorem shines: ''h'' is a continuous function on [0,1], hence for any value ''N'' between ''h''(0) and ''h''(1) there exists a number ''c'' = ''c''(''N'') such that
:<math>
\displaystyle h(c) = N.
</math>

Since we have shown that ''h''(0) is negative and ''h''(1) is positive, we can choose that value ''N'' to be exactly zero and thus the Intermediate Value Theorem guarantees the existence of a number ''c'' in the interval [0,1] such that ''h''(''c'') = 0.

Conclusion: At this value ''c'' we have that
:<math>
0 = h(c) = f(c) - (2c+3)
</math>
or, in other words, ''f''(''c'') = 2''c''+3, which is what we had to show.
statement_html:
Full-Solution Problems. In questions 2-8, justify your answers and show all your work. If a box is provided, write your final answer there. Simplification of answers is not required unless explicitly stated.

If y = \(f(x)\) is a continuous function with domain [0,1] and range in [3,5], prove that the line y = 2x + 3 intersects the graph of y = \(f(x)\) at least once.
statement_latex:
\emph{\textbf{Full-Solution Problems.} In questions 2-8, justify your
answers and \textbf{show all your work.} If a box is provided, write
your final answer there. Simplification of answers is not required
unless explicitly stated.}

If \emph{y} = $f(x)$ is a continuous function with domain {[}0,1{]}
and range in {[}3,5{]}, prove that the line \emph{y} = 2\emph{x} + 3
intersects the graph of \emph{y} = $f(x)$ at least once.

If ''y'' = &fnof;(''x'') is a continuous function with domain [0,1] and range in [3,5], prove that the line ''y'' = 2''x'' + 3 intersects the graph of ''y'' = &fnof;(''x'') at least once.
